title: Isolation of spermatogenic cells from the cynomolgus macaque testis with flow cytometry
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Testis dissection
Timing: 30 min
The following steps are carried out to isolate seminiferous tubules from the macaque testis for enzymatic digestion.
Perform testis dissection is on a 10 cm petri dish (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/428-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Cynomolgus macaque testis dissection
(A) Image of an adult cynomolgus macaque testis.
(B) Detachment of the epididymis from the testis.
(C) Small incision of the tunica albuginea.
(D) Dissection of tunica albuginea and separation of the seminiferous tubules from the tunica albuginea.
(E) Segmentation of testis tubule tissue into 1–2 g pieces.
Remove the outer layers, e.g., skin and loose connective tissue.
Detach the epididymis.
Weigh the testis.
Remove the tunica albuginea.
Make a small incision of the tunica albuginea.
Dissect under it to create a dissection plane, separating the seminiferous tubules underneath from the tunica.
Cut the testis tubules into 1 - 2 g pieces, and further cut each piece into smaller pieces to facilitate subsequent digestion.
Dissociation of testis samples
Timing: 1 h
The subsequent steps are performed to obtain a single-cell suspension of unselected cells from seminiferous tubules using enzymatic digestion.
Submerge testis tubule pieces in 25 mL of Tissue Digest Buffer A and leave the samples to digest at 37°C in a water bath for 5 min.
Shake the tube vigorously every 2 min until loosened tubules become visible.
Remove and discard the supernatant.
Optional: Cells in the supernatant, i.e., primarily interstitial cells, may also be kept and processed separately if this is of interest.
Add 25 mL of Tissue Digest Buffer B and allow the digest to occur for 30 min at 37°C in a water bath.
Shake the tube vigorously every 2 min until dissociation of the tubules into a single-cell suspension of cells.

Add 2.5 mL of FBS to stop digestion.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 200 × g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 25 mL of PBS
Repeat steps 9 and 10.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 200 × g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the cells in a desired volume of PBS.
Filter the cell suspension through a 40 μm cell strainer into a fresh tube.
Count the cells to determine cell concentration.
Sample preparation for spermatocyte fluorescence-activated cell sorting
Timing: 45 min
Steps 16–20 describe live cells staining with the Hoechst 33342.
Aliquot the appropriate number of cells into four tubes.
Unstained control: 1 × 106 cells
PI only control: 1 × 106 cells
Hoechst 33342 only control: 1 × 106 cells
PI + Hoechst 33342 sample: 5 × 106 to 1 × 107 cells
Note: Tubes a - c serve as single stained controls used for gating and assessing fluorescence spectral overlap purposes. Assessment of the spectrum of spermatogenic cells can then be gated and analyzed using Tube d.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 200 × g for 10 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the matching cell pellet tube with 1 mL of prepared stain solution.
Incubate tubes at 37°C for 30 min in the dark. Agitate tubes every 10 min to resuspend cells thus ensuring uniform staining.
Note: Incubation with Hoechst 33342 stain has to be performed for at least 30 min at 37°C for optimal resolution.
Tubes are kept on ice, protected from light and filtered using a 40μm cell strainer prior to analysis.
Sample preparation for spermatogonia fluorescence-activated cell sorting
Timing: 45 min
Steps 21–28 describe live cell staining with SSEA-4 APC-conjugated antibody for the isolation of spermatogonia.

Aliquot the appropriate number of cells into three tubes.
Unstained control: 1 × 106 cells
PI only control: 1 × 106 cells
PI + SSEA-4 APC-conjugated Ab sample: 1 × 107 cells
Note: Tubes a and b serve as single stained controls used for gating and assessing fluorescence spectral overlap purposes. Tube c contains all fluorochromes of interest involved in the cell sorting assay.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 200 × g for 10 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the matching cell pellet tube with 1 mL of prepared SSEA-4 APC-conjugated Ab stain solution. Incubate tubes at 37°C for 30 min in the dark. Agitate tubes every 10 min to resuspend cells.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 200 × g for 10 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend cell pellet and wash twice with DPBS to remove unbound SSEA-4-APC-conjugated antibodies.
Resuspend cells with DPBS + 10% FBS at a density of 2 to 3 million cells/mL for the sort.
Add 1 μg/mL of PI and filter the stained cell suspension using a 40μm cell strainer prior to cell sorting.
Tubes are kept on ice and protected from light before cell sorting.
Gating strategy for isolating primary spermatocytes
Timing: 20 min
Steps 29–34 describe the gating strategy to use on the BD FACS Diva software for isolation of primary spermatocytes at various meiotic sub-stages of prophase I.
Create an FSC-A versus SSC-A contour plot (linear scale). Draw a “Scatter” gate to include cells of interest while excluding debris.
On the FSC-A versus FSC-H contour plot (linear scale), create a sub-gate under the “Scatter” gate to encompass single cells. This step helps to omit doublets which could otherwise contaminate purity of the sorted cells.

Next, gate on PI negative live cells under the Singlets Gate using a PI-A (log scale) versus FSC-A (linear scale) contour.
Display all live viable events on a DNA histogram with Hoechst blue on the x axis and count on the y axis. Low Hoechst blue intensity events are excluded to omit debris and unstained cells. Draw a “DNA” gate to only include cells containing DNA content of 1C and greater. Data are collected in linear scale.
View gated “DNA” events on the Hoechst red-A/Hoechst blue-A contour plot (linear scale). A spectrum of cells in varying stages of spermatogenesis can be identified and gated based on their DNA content and Hoechst red/Hoechst blue fluorescence profile (please refer to Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]F for more details on the profile obtained).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/428-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Flow cytometry analysis and gating of primary spermatocytes
(A) Gating strategy for isolating primary spermatocytes.
(B) Scatter gate drawn from unstained control to include cells of interest while excluding debris. Baseline voltages for the sample and level of autofluorescence in sample can be determined without the addition of fluorochromes.
(C) Singlet gate drawn to omit doublets which may contribute to false positives.
(D) Gate on PI negative live cells drawn from PI only control to determine cell viability.
(E) DNA gate to determine spread of cells based on nucleic acid content from Hoechst only control, and exclude cells less than 1C.
(F) Gates drawn for the collection of enriched primary spermatocytes based on their stages of meiotic prophase I.
Create 4 gates and label them A, B, C, and D. These gates represent cell populations that are enriched in primary spermatocytes at pre-leptotene, leptotene/zygotene, early pachytene, late pachytene meiotic stages respectively (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).

Note: PI is a nucleic acid stain that enters dead cells with disrupted cell membranes, and is excluded from live ones with intact membranes. The live cell dye Hoechst 33342 on the other hand is able to enter cells through diffusion and binds to the nucleic acid residues on the minor groove of DNA. Hoechst allows the detection variation in DNA content and chromatin, and in meiotic cells Hoechst red/blue fluorescence can be used to discriminate subpopulation of cells undergoing meiosis I (Bastos et al., 2005[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]). Similarly, in this protocol, PI is used to reliably discriminate live cells (i.e., intact PI negative cells) versus non-viable (PI positive) cells, and Hoechst fluorescence is used to discriminate on the DNA content of meiotic cells.
Note: Similar Hoechst 33342 staining profiles can be obtained using different brands of flow cytometers equipped with the laser lines described above. Filter configurations can differ between different systems.
Flow cytometry analysis and fluorescence-activated cell sorting for primary spermatocytes
Timing: 40 min
In this section, testis cells are sorted according to their Hoechst blue/Hoechst red fluorescence. Gated primary spermatocytes at various meiotic prophase I sub-stages are collected from the sort.
Using the gating template created above, acquire samples and optimize photomultiplier tube (PMT) voltages using the single stain controls in the following sequence (unstained, PI only, Hoechst 33342 only).
Note: This step ensures that signals captured are on scale and also allows us to access fluorochrome interactions with one another (spectral overlap).
Unstained tube
Sets baseline voltages for the sample.
Determines the level of autofluorescence in the sample without adding any fluorochromes (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Select and gate for singlets (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C). Omit doublets which may contribute to false positive signals.
PI only control tube

Allows for the assessment of PI negative live and PI positive dead cells. Cell viability can be determined from the percentages of PI negative cells that did not stain with propidium iodide (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D).
Hoechst 33342 only control tube
Determines the spread of cells based on their nucleic acid content on the Hoechst blue histogram (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]E).
Bi-parameter display of Hoechst blue/Hoechst red fluorescence signals allows for the assessment of cells in varying stages of spermatogenesis.
Acquire and record 10,000 to 50,000 events in these tubes.
Check the Hoechst profile of viable (PI negative) cells using the Hoechst 33342 + PI-stained tube using the optimized PMT settings above.
Record a minimum of 500,000 events before establishing gates for primary spermatocytes.
Define and gate cells based on their Hoechst fluorescence pattern, which corresponds to their DNA content (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]F). The shift in Hoechst red and Hoechst blue corresponds to the meiotic progression of primary spermatocytes, which allows for the discrimination of sub-stages of meiotic prophase I.
Gate 4N primary spermatocytes, based on their distinct sub-stages, following the contours of the cell density.
Program to collect and sort cells.
Sort cells using a low flow rate with 70 μm nozzle at 70 psi. Maintain event rate around 2,000–3,500 events/s.
Note: High flow rates can increase the speed of cell sorting but compromise sort purity of the isolated fractions.
Maintain a minimum of >80% sort efficiency during the sort. Monitor discard rate throughout to ensure that is it preferably not >200 events/s.
Collect sorted cells in round bottom FACS tubes pre-loaded with collection media.

Note: It is important to pre-coat the interior of collection tubes with collection media as this reduces the chances of sorted cells sticking to the interior of the tube during collection. 10% FBS in collection media enhances the survival of sorted fractions.
To store cells, centrifuge to pellet collected cells at 200 × g for 10 min at 4°C.
Discard supernatant and resuspend cells in Freezing Media to a concentration of 1000 cells/μL.
Aliquot 100–200 μL of cell suspension in cryovials and store at −80°C.
Gating strategy for isolating spermatogonia
Timing: 20 min
Steps 43–46 describe the gating strategy to use on the BD FACS Diva software for isolation of SSEA-4 positive spermatogonia.
Create an FSC-A versus SSC-A contour plot (linear scale). Draw a “Scatter” gate to include cells of interest while excluding debris.
On the FSC-A versus FSC-H contour plot (linear scale), create a sub-gate under the “Scatter” gate to encompass single cells. This step helps to omit doublets which could otherwise contaminate purity of the sorted cells.
Next, gate on PI negative live cells under the Singlets Gate using a PI-A (log scale) versus FSC-A (linear scale) contour.
Create 2 gates and label them SSEA4- and SSEA4+. These gates represent cells that are negatively or positively stained with anti-SSEA-4 APC-conjugated antibody (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).

(A) Gating strategy for isolating spermatogonia.
(B) Scatter gate drawn from unstained control to include cells of interest while excluding debris. Baseline voltages for the sample and level of autofluorescence in sample can be determined without the addition of fluorochromes.

(E) Gates drawn for the collection of SSEA-4 negative and positive cells.
Fluorescence-activated cell sorting for spermatogonia
Timing: 40 min
In this section, testis cells are sorted based on the presence of APC fluorescence and SSEA-4 positive spermatogonia are collected.
Using the gating template created above, acquire samples and optimize photomultiplier tube (PMT) voltages using the single stain controls in the following sequence (unstained, PI only, Hoechst 33342 only).
Note: This step ensures that signals captured are on scale and also allows us to access fluorochrome interactions with one another (spectral overlap).
Unstained tube
Sets baseline voltages for the sample
Determines the level of autofluorescence in the sample without adding any fluorochromes (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Select and gate for singlets. Omit doublets which may contribute to false positive signals (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
PI only control tube. Allows for the assessment of viable PI negative and PI positive dead cells. Cell viability can be determined from the percentages of PI negative cells that did not take up propidium iodide (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D).
Acquire and analyze the PI + SSEA-4 APC-conjugated Ab sample tube.
Record a minimum of 100,000 events before establishing gates.
Cells are gated and selected for SSEA-4-positivity (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]E).
Program to collect and sort PI negative SSEA-4-APC positive cells.
Sort cells using a low flow rate with 70 μm nozzle at 70 psi. Maintain event rate around 2,000–3,500 events/s.
Note: High flow rates can increase the speed of cell sorting but compromise sort purity of the isolated fractions.
Maintain a minimum of >80% sort efficiency during the sort. Monitor discard rate throughout to ensure that is it preferably not >200 events/s.
Collect sorted cells in round bottom FACS tubes pre-loaded with collection media.

Note: It is important to pre-coat the interior of collection tubes with collection media as this reduces the chances of sorted cells sticking to the interior of the tube during collection. 10% FBS in collection media enhances the survival of sorted fractions.
To store cells, centrifuge to pellet collected cells at 200 × g for 10 min at 4°C.
Discard supernatant and resuspend cells in Freezing Media to a concentration of 1000 cells/μL.
Aliquot 100–200 μL of cell suspension in cryovials and store at −80°C.
